update.description:
This PR implements the option to use an external libccd instead of using the embedded copy inside gazebo. It is disabled by default, so internal copy will be used unless specified when running cmake. This is needed to go into debian and keep the sync with DART.

For testing this, we have the libccd 1.4 version in a [PPA](https://launchpad.net/~libccd-debs/+archive/ppa) (created for DART) or download the [two](https://www.dropbox.com/s/57u51tsl5nen0zm/libccd2_1.5-1_amd64.deb) [packages](https://www.dropbox.com/s/pnii8se4823aa5h/libccd-dev_1.5-1_amd64.deb) I did for the inclusion into debian, version 1.5.
update.title: Support to use an external libccd

pull_request.title: Support to use an external libccd

pullrequest.title: Support to use an external libccd

content.raw: I don't think it's necessary for the build.  This logic was being used before this pr was made without any issues.  When you call target_link_libraries with a cmake target name instead of an external lib name, cmake does the extra work to make sure the new target depends on your specified target, and resolves the library location for you.  When you run "make VERBOSE=1" without an external libccd detected you should see the absolute path to the gazebo_ccd library on the linker command line for gazebo_ode
content.html: I don't think it's necessary for the build. This logic was being used before this pr was made without any issues. When you call target_link_libraries with a cmake target name instead of an external lib name, cmake does the extra work to make sure the new target depends on your specified target, and resolves the library location for you. When you run "make VERBOSE=1" without an external libccd detected you should see the absolute path to the gazebo_ccd library on the linker command line for gazebo_ode

pullrequest.title: Support to use an external libccd

content.raw:
I see, thanks, fixed now. Much better place the include and link directives in the proper CMakeLists.txt so we don't generate an unneeded 'overflaging' in the rest of the project/targets.

The ideal situation should be refined the link and include directories by target (using set_target_properties) but we need to deprecate Precise first (cmake in Precise does not support it).
content.html:
I see, thanks, fixed now. Much better place the include and link directives in the proper CMakeLists.txt so we don't generate an unneeded 'overflaging' in the rest of the project/targets.

The ideal situation should be refined the link and include directories by target (using set_target_properties) but we need to deprecate Precise first (cmake in Precise does not support it).

pull_request.title: Support to use an external libccd

pullrequest.title: Support to use an external libccd

content.raw:
CCD_INCLUDE_DIRS and CCD_LIBRARIES work because they've already been coded into the rest of the Gazebo cmake files.  If you look at the lines you deleted:

-  set(CCD_INCLUDE_DIRS "${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/deps/libccd/include")

-  set(CCD_LIBRARIES gazebo_ccd)

you see that the buildsystem was already using those variables to set ccd vars before your change.  The deps/opende/CMakeLists.txt verifies this: it calls include_directories using CCD_INCLUDE_DIRS, link_directories using CCD_LIBRARY_DIRS, and target_link_libraries uisng CCD_LIBRARIES.  This amazing coincidence is because ccd was actually already detected by pkgconfig in the past.  That functionality was  was reverted in this commit for some reason:

#!/osrf/gazebo/commits/42465fbec0a25976b9c5f5c3d8eda1367fe43fd3
content.html:
CCD_INCLUDE_DIRS and CCD_LIBRARIES work because they've already been coded into the rest of the Gazebo cmake files. If you look at the lines you deleted:

  • set(CCD_INCLUDE_DIRS "${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/deps/libccd/include")

  • set(CCD_LIBRARIES gazebo_ccd)

you see that the buildsystem was already using those variables to set ccd vars before your change. The deps/opende/CMakeLists.txt verifies this: it calls include_directories using CCD_INCLUDE_DIRS, link_directories using CCD_LIBRARY_DIRS, and target_link_libraries uisng CCD_LIBRARIES. This amazing coincidence is because ccd was actually already detected by pkgconfig in the past. That functionality was was reverted in this commit for some reason:

#!/osrf/gazebo/commits/42465fbec0a25976b9c5f5c3d8eda1367fe43fd3

pull_request.title: Support to use an external libccd

pullrequest.title: Support to use an external libccd

content.raw:
Thanks very much Rich. I have removed the INTERNAL_LIBCCD variable. About not using ```include_directories``` or ```link_directories``` I agree that CCD_* variables are set pkg-config but, are they reaching the compiler arguments when building? How?

My hypothesis, I could be totally wrong, is that in your case is working just because the libccd is installed into the default system paths. We have tried using non standard installations (take our experiment on homebrew as an example) and [have failures](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-patched_protobuf-homebrew_bcn-amd64/11/console) while using pkg-config and [they were fixed](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/988/fix-ffmpeg-detection-gazebo_22/diff) declaring the ```include_directories``` or ```link_directories```. Let me know if there is a better way of doing this.

Thanks again!
content.html:
Thanks very much Rich. I have removed the INTERNAL_LIBCCD variable. About not using include_directories or link_directories I agree that CCD_* variables are set pkg-config but, are they reaching the compiler arguments when building? How?

My hypothesis, I could be totally wrong, is that in your case is working just because the libccd is installed into the default system paths. We have tried using non standard installations (take our experiment on homebrew as an example) and have failures while using pkg-config and they were fixed declaring the include_directories or link_directories. Let me know if there is a better way of doing this.

Thanks again!

This PR implements the option to use an external libccd instead of using the embedded copy inside gazebo. It is disabled by default, so internal copy will be used unless specified when running cmake. This is needed to go into debian and keep the sync with DART.

For testing this, we have the libccd 1.4 version in a [PPA](https://launchpad.net/~libccd-debs/+archive/ppa) (created for DART) or download the [two](https://www.dropbox.com/s/57u51tsl5nen0zm/libccd2_1.5-1_amd64.deb) [packages](https://www.dropbox.com/s/pnii8se4823aa5h/libccd-dev_1.5-1_amd64.deb) I did for the inclusion into debian, version 1.5.

pull_request.title: Support to use an external libccd

pullrequest.title: Support to use an external libccd

content.raw:
This section only needs to be:

pkg_check_modules(CCD ccd >= 1.4)

if (NOT CCD_FOUND)

  set(CCD_INCLUDE_DIRS "${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/deps/libccd/include")

  set(CCD_LIBRARIES gazebo_ccd) 

endif (NOT CCD_FOUND)


pkg-config sets CCD_INCLUDE_DIRS and CCD_LIBRARIES for you, you don't need to do include_directories or link_directories.  You also don't really need INTERNAL_LIBCCD, since it's always just NOT CCD_FOUND.  The above is what I use in the Fedora package (that change is mixed into http://rmattes.fedorapeople.org/RPMS/gazebo/gazebo-2.2.2-fedora.patch)
content.html:
This section only needs to be:

pkg_check_modules(CCD ccd >= 1.4)

if (NOT CCD_FOUND)

set(CCD_INCLUDE_DIRS "${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/deps/libccd/include")

set(CCD_LIBRARIES gazebo_ccd)

endif (NOT CCD_FOUND)

pkg-config sets CCD_INCLUDE_DIRS and CCD_LIBRARIES for you, you don't need to do include_directories or link_directories. You also don't really need INTERNAL_LIBCCD, since it's always just NOT CCD_FOUND. The above is what I use in the Fedora package (that change is mixed into http://rmattes.fedorapeople.org/RPMS/gazebo/gazebo-2.2.2-fedora.patch)

pull_request.title: Support to use an external libccd

pullrequest.title: Support to use an external libccd

content.raw:
This is a good point. This is not the standard way of handling optional support in gazebo, that is right, but we won't have an alternative option for the rest of dependencies (no embedded copy). The flag is on by default just to keep backwards compatibility during the transition and use it specially for debian packaging.

I'm going to change it so it behaves the same way that the rest of optional support, but as a future work I would recommend change all the optional support to be enabled using [options](http://www.cmake.org/cmake/help/v2.8.8/cmake.html#command:option).
content.html:
This is a good point. This is not the standard way of handling optional support in gazebo, that is right, but we won't have an alternative option for the rest of dependencies (no embedded copy). The flag is on by default just to keep backwards compatibility during the transition and use it specially for debian packaging.

I'm going to change it so it behaves the same way that the rest of optional support, but as a future work I would recommend change all the optional support to be enabled using options.

pull_request.title: Support to use an external libccd

pullrequest.title: Support to use an external libccd

content.raw:
This flag seems to break with the standard way external libraries are used. This opt-out approach means that we prefer the built-in libcdd instead of the external libccd. It'd be very easy to install the external libccd, and compile gazebo without using the external library.

The end goal is to also remove this flag, correct? Wouldn't it be better to use & test the library detection code from the start?
content.html:
This flag seems to break with the standard way external libraries are used. This opt-out approach means that we prefer the built-in libcdd instead of the external libccd. It'd be very easy to install the external libccd, and compile gazebo without using the external library.

The end goal is to also remove this flag, correct? Wouldn't it be better to use & test the library detection code from the start?

pull_request.title: Support to use an external libccd

pullrequest.title: Support to use an external libccd

content.raw: I consider the flag as a more robust approach or less error prone. You can explicitly say what you like to use instead of use a implicit mechanism. If for some reason the detection code is buggy, the error is somewhat 'hidden' and the compilation will finish just fine making the error harder to detect than if you get a failing compilation.
content.html: I consider the flag as a more robust approach or less error prone. You can explicitly say what you like to use instead of use a implicit mechanism. If for some reason the detection code is buggy, the error is somewhat 'hidden' and the compilation will finish just fine making the error harder to detect than if you get a failing compilation.

content.html: Right, I guess I should have asked why do we need this argument. If the external library exists, then use it. Otherwise use the internal
